video.title_en: Oersted's experiment (& magnetic field due to current)

summary.text_en: During a lecture demonstration, Danish physicist Hans Christian Ã˜rsted accidentally discovered an epochal phenomenon: when a wire carrying an 'electric current' (from a Voltaic Pile, `volta_battery_1800`) was brought near a 'magnetic compass', the compass needle *deflected*. This was the first time in history that a *link* was experimentally proven between 'electricity' and 'magnetism'â€”two forces previously thought to be completely separate. This discovery founded the entire field of 'Electromagnetism'.
key_points_en: Proved that an electric *current* produces a *magnetic field*
Experiment: Current deflects a compass needle

story.text_en: In April 1820, Ã˜rsted was giving a lecture on electricity (from a battery) and magnetism (from a lodestone), which everyone assumed were separate. On a whim, he decided to see what would happen if he passed a current *over* a compass needle. To his (and his students') astonishment, the moment the current from the `volta_battery_1800` was switched on, the compass needle *violently deflected* 90 degrees, perpendicular to the wire. He turned the current off; the needle returned to north. He had discovered that *electricity creates magnetism*. He spent three months confirming the effect, then published his short Latin paper in July 1820, setting off a firestorm across the European scientific world.

fun_facts.text_en: This world-changing discovery was made 'by accident' during a (possibly badly-prepared) lecture to students.
In his honor, the CGS unit of magnetic field strength is named the 'Oersted' (Oe).
Ã˜rsted also discovered the magnetic field was *circular* around the wire (the 'right-hand rule'), a completely new kind of force that didn't point 'to' or 'from' the source, like gravity.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Before 1820, everyone thought 'electricity' (from a battery) and 'magnetism' (from a magnet) were totally separate things, like 'apples' and 'oranges'.
Ã˜rsted, during a lecture, accidentally put a *wire with electricity flowing through it* over a *compass*. The compass needle *went crazy*.
This proved: electricity and magnetism are *related*! He showed that when electricity *flows* (a current), it *creates* an invisible magnetic field around the wire. This was the birth of 'electromagnetism'.

applications.text_en: This discovery was the 'first domino' that led Faraday (`faraday_induction_1831`) and Maxwell (`maxwell_equations_1861`) to build the unified theory of electromagnetism.

impact.text_en: Ã˜rsted's discovery was one of the most important of the 19th century. It built the 'bridge' between electricity and magnetism, founding the new science of 'electromagnetism'. It led *directly* to Faraday's invention of the motor and generator, and to Maxwell's unified field theory (which included light). Our entire modern world of electricity and communication (radio, internet) began with that twitching compass needle in his classroom.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Volta's Battery (provided the first 'steady, continuous' source of current needed for the experiment)

James Clerk Maxwell (his 'First Equation' is the mathematical formalization of Ã˜rsted's 'current creates magnetism' discovery)
Samuel Morse (his telegraph 'sounder'â€”an electromagnetâ€”worked on Ã˜rsted's principle)

quiz.question_en: What relationship between electricity and magnetism did Hans Christian Ã˜rsted discover in his 1820 experiment?
options_en: That a magnetic field can create an electric current (Magnetism creates Electricity)
That an electric current can create a magnetic field (Electricity creates Magnetism)
That electricity and magnetism are two totally separate forces
That electricity can be neutralized by magnetism
quiz.explanation_en: Ã˜rsted's experiment proved 'Electricity creates Magnetism': when he turned the 'current' on, a 'magnetic field' appeared and moved the compass. This is the inverse of Faraday's (`faraday_induction_1831`) discovery ('Magnetism creates Electricity').
